issue.title: Fix shape inference for DequantizeLinear
issue.body:
### Description
Fix shape inference for types float16 and bfloat16 for operator DequantizeLinear.

### Motivation and Context
Shape inference is wrong for DequanzeLinear-19 as reported in issue #5704.

pull_request.title: Fix shape inference for DequantizeLinear
pull_request.body:
### Description
Fix shape inference for types float16 and bfloat16 for operator DequantizeLinear.

### Motivation and Context
Shape inference is wrong for DequanzeLinear-19 as reported in issue #5704.

issue.title: Is it legal that 2 onnx Loop nodes in a model have body subgraph with nodes of identical name?
issue.body:
# Ask a Question

### Question

Hi, I have an ONNX model that has 2 onnx Loop nodes, say Loop A and Loop B.
In Loop A's body subgraph, there is an Add node with the name "my_add".
In Loop B's body subgraph, there is also an Add node with the identical name "my_add".
**Is this illegal or legal, according to ONNX rules? (2 subgraphs having nodes with identical names)**

In addition, suppose that Loop A's body subgraph has an output with the name "my_output", and so does Loop B.
**Is this illegal or legal? (2 subgraphs having outputs with identical names)**

Thanks a lot for your kind reply :-)

comment.body:
@xadupre  Thanks a lot for your timely reply!
In fact, the situation I am meeting is not nested loops, but two separate loop nodes.
The ONNX model is like this:
              ... other nodes ...
                |                    |
            Loop A          Loop B 
                |                    |
              ... other nodes ...
Inside Loop A (body subgraph):
                max_trip    cond          y_in    ------> inputs
                     \              |             /
                       ... some nodes ...
                                    |
                              Add node (name = "Add_522")
                                    |
                       ... some nodes ...
                     /             |              \
           cond_out         y_out       scan_out   ---------> outputs
 (name = "cond_234")
Inside Loop B (body subgraph):
                max_trip    cond          y_in    ------> inputs
                     \              |             /
                       ... some nodes ...
                                    |
                              Add node (name = "Add_522")
                                    |
                       ... some nodes ...
                     /             |              \
           cond_out         y_out       scan_out   ---------> outputs
 (name = "cond_234")

For this case, what I really wonder is:
1. There is a node with the name "Add_522" inside Loop A, and simultaneously there is another node with an identical name "Add_522". Is this illegal?
2. Loop A's body subgraph has an output with the name "cond_234", and simultaneously Loop B's body subgraph also has an output with the name "cond_234". Is this illegal?

Thx again for your response!

issue.title: [Resize] which conversion mode should be taken in RESIZE output_dim computation, Floor or Round?
issue.body:
# Ask a Question

output_dim computation is not unified on how to convert float to int.
Is this a bug?

### Question
In Resize-18, `keep_aspect_ratio_policy ` has three different options, "stretch","not_larger","not_smaller".

We have round mode when `policy` is not the default from the spec:
`out_size[d] = round_int(scale * in_size[i])`

However, for the default policy, `stretch`,  we have floor instead to calculate the output shape.

The question is, Python.float is not mapping to cpp.float. so we get a shape different eventually.

### Further information

One of the cases where we will run into the output-shape in-consistency.

Say we want to do  Resize operations for image which has shape (224,224), enlarge it into (706,706) firstly, then we want to resize back to (224,224) . Apprently, if we want  to make this work and can give it a scale, (224/706,224/706). Then things are in a mess in C++, because 224*(224/706)=223.99999999, if it's truncated into INT with floor, we got 223, which is not expected as we want.

Python does work for this case, since python.float is same as cpp.double.
### Notes
<!-- Any additional information, code snippets. -->

comment.body:
Additionally the current [computation here](https://github.com/onnx/onnx/blob/b5e1378a35b24a4316900c69b71214cac7ca5736/onnx/defs/tensor/utils.cc#L137)...
 
```
int64_t dim_value =
          static_cast<int64_t>(std::floor(static_cast<float>(input_shape.dim(i).dim_value()) * scales_data[i]));
```

...has an issue that some output sizes cannot be faithfully represented, as performing the computation in float32 before casting to integer means some integer spaces will not be hit.

For a simple example (although excessively large, it's simple and doesn't involve any explicit rounding or decimal points), take:

```
input width = 16777217
scale = 1.0
expected output width = 16777217
computed output width = 16777216
```
That's definitely incorrect, as x times 1 should equal x. This happens because the result 16777217 can't fit in float32 which becomes 16777216. Computing the intermediate in double would ensure the accurate output width of 16777217.

pull_request.title: Bump CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD as 17 globally
pull_request.body:
### Description
<!-- - Describe your changes. -->
- Bump CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD as 17 globally (Windows and non-Windows).
- Update README.md accordingly.

### Motivation and Context
<!-- - Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!-- - If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Currently by default onnx uses CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD 17 on Windows, but by contrast it uses CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD 14 on other platforms. It's a bit confusing. Also it blocks onnx utilizing C++ 17 features. Trying this PR to verify ONNX CI Pipelines with this update. If no one has other concern, we will target next release (possibly 1.16) to include this CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD bump. Users who build their onnx from their own are still able to specify their own CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD version.

Anyone has any question/concern, feel free to chime in. Thanks!

<!--
copilot:all
-->
### <samp>🤖 Generated by Copilot at a1c07ad</samp>

### Summary
🧹🔄📝

<!--
1.  🧹 - This emoji represents the simplification and cleanup of the CMake logic for setting the C++ standard version.
2.  🔄 - This emoji represents the consistency and alignment of the C++ standard version across platforms and the possibility of overriding it with a custom value.
3.  📝 - This emoji represents the documentation update in the README.md file.
-->
Simplify and unify the C++ standard version setting for ONNX. Update the `README.md` file accordingly.

> _`CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD`_
> _Simpler and consistent now_
> _Autumn of cleanup_

### Walkthrough
*  Simplify CMake logic for setting C++ standard version ([link](https://github.com/onnx/onnx/pull/5612/files?diff=unified&w=0#diff-1e7de1ae2d059d21e1dd75d5812d5a34b0222cef273b7c3a2af62eb747f9d20aL58-R59))
* Update README documentation to match CMake changes ([link](https://github.com/onnx/onnx/pull/5612/files?diff=unified&w=0#diff-b335630551682c19a781afebcf4d07bf978fb1f8ac04c6bf87428ed5106870f5L114-R114))

issue.title: infer old squeeze on known input shape and empty axes
issue.body: the shape inference of squeeze 13 can handle the case that the input shape is known and the axes is unspecified, but that of older version squeezes not. This PR fixes it.

issue.title: Spec issue: GridSample
issue.body:
This is a collection of issues encountered with GridSample in the ONNX spec.

It's not clear to me if this is the proper method/format/venue to report these - let me know if I should be doing something else.

For reference: [current ONNX spec for GridSample](https://github.com/onnx/onnx/blob/main/docs/Operators.md#GridSample) and [PyTorch GridSample](https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/generated/torch.nn.functional.grid_sample.html)

I also have [a draft spec change proposal](https://github.com/broune/onnx/blob/main/docs/Operators.md#GridSample), which simply makes some assumptions about how the issues below will be resolved and so would likely need some updates later. Regardless of those decisions, this draft is far more detailed in explaining the behavior of GridSample than anything else I've seen, and may be useful for anyone seeing this who has not spent a lot of time looking at GridSample recently. (I also can't figure out how to display LaTeX equations in the spec, as you will notice if you read that link, is LaTeX possible / allowed in the spec?)

## Errors
1) The description of how the reflection padding_mode works for points close to the border is true for align_corners=0 but not when align_corners=1 (which moves the axis of mirroring, so it’s different). Both the Microsoft ONNX implementation and PyTorch do something different for align_corners=1 and doing so is also consistent with the description in the spec of how this works for points far from the border.

2) The spec allows the grid input to contain complex numbers without defining what that means. I don’t know what it would mean to access an array at a complex number (with or without interpolation) and I think allowing this is an error.

3) The X input is allowed to be a complex number (which is fine), but the output type specification does not include a complex number, which seems like an error, since complex number input would yield complex number output (assuming the obvious interpretation of how complex number input should be handled).

## Missing details
4) The spec does not specify how normalized coordinates are denormalized.

5) The spec does not specify that the minor coordinate comes before the major coordinate, though it can be seen from the first example (which matches PyTorch). This is surprising and opposite from the order in gather_nd, so would be good to specify explicitly.

6) It’s not specified what the element type of the output should be. If the X input is floating point, it makes sense that the output would use the same element type, but this is not specified anywhere. Also, in that case, what precision should internal calculations use? This is a bigger question for integer inputs - it’s really not clear what the output type should then be. Presumably some floating point type.
 
7) The spec doesn't say anything about what happens in the padding mode "nearest" when there is a tie where a grid point is equally close to two or more integer points. This shows up as a denormalized coordinate ending in ".5" and the question is whether to round it up or down. There is an example provided in the spec using "nearest" padding and that example has several ties in it. If we leave this unspecified, so that any implementation is allowed, it would be good for the spec to say that and for the provided example in the spec to not contain this case (it currently does) so that the correct answer is unambiguous. Note that the Resize op does specify how rounding should be done, providing several options, we could specify the same.
 
8) This op is unusual in that inherently-imprecise floating point calculations are used as indices into arrays. If the grid points are so large that one ulp exceeds 1.0, then the results can be arbitrarily imprecise and there is a problem for implementations casting to integer points. The spec ought to address this, I’d prefer by saying that such large grid points can yield arbitrary results, freeing implementations from having to do arbitrary-precision calculations to fit the spec.
 
## Minor points
9) The grid operand is allowed to be integer. This will hit the grid only at integer points (corner points), which it is not clear that anyone would want to do. If we continue to allow this, it might be good for the spec to acknowledge that it’s supported but probably would indicate a mistake to use it.

10) The X operand is allowed to be a complex number. This works out easily mathematically, but it might be good for the spec to acknowledge that the simple interpretation of treating the real and imaginary components as independent dimensions is the intended interpretation. (Unless we didn’t intend to support complex numbers here at all?)

## Further points for discussion
11) ONNX only allows 4D points for GridSample but PyTorch also allows 5D inputs. Conceivably 3D inputs with a time dimension might get into 6D. Should we allow 5D dimensions? How about 6D dimensions?

12) Beyond rounding mode, Resize also allows setting the alpha parameter for bicubic interpolation. Should we allow alpha (and rounding mode, but there’s a separate point about that above) to be set for bicubic interpolation on GridSample as well?

comment.body: Marked for discussion. Anyone interested please feel free to chime in

Numpy helper `from_dict` raises type error fix (#5543)

### Description
<!-- - Describe your changes. -->
Improves (hopefully) how `from_dict` determines the numpy type of
dictionary keys and values by using
[`numpy.result_type`](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.result_type.html#numpy-result-type).

### Motivation and Context
<!-- - Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!-- - If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Trying to solve #5522. This PR alone doesn't fully address the issue
raised, because the example given in the issue has bare floats as
dictionary values, while code in `numpy_helper.py` seems to expect
tensors to already be `numpy.array`s or similar types.

So an open question is should `from_dict` support non-numpy types as
tensors?

---------

Signed-off-by: Clif Houck <me@clifhouck.com>

fixes it.

### Motivation and Context
onnx CI does not use machine with CUDA and some unit tests may fail.

parameters.

Bump ruff from 0.0.284 to 0.0.286 (#5560) Bumps [ruff](https://github.com/astral-sh/ruff) from 0.0.284 to 0.0.286.
Release notes

Sourced from ruff's releases.

v0.0.286

What's Changed

New Rules

  • [flake8-bugbear] Update function-call-in-argument-default (B008) to ignore arguments with immutable annotations by @​zanieb in astral-sh/ruff#6784
  • [flake8-bugbear] Update mutable-argument-default (B006) to use extend-immutable-calls when determining if annotations are immutable by @​zanieb in astral-sh/ruff#6781
  • [flake8-pie] Implement unnecessary-range-start (PIE808) by @​harupy in astral-sh/ruff#6690
  • [flake8-pytest-style] Add autofix for PT014 by @​harupy in astral-sh/ruff#6698
  • [pylint] Implement no-self-use (R6301) by @​LaBatata101 in astral-sh/ruff#6574
  • [pylint] Extend repeated-equality-comparison-target to check for mixed orderings and Yoda conditions. by @​tjkuson in astral-sh/ruff#6691

Settings

  • Make isort's detect-same-package behavior configurable by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6833

Bug Fixes

  • Apply RUF017 when start is passed via position by @​hauntsaninja in astral-sh/ruff#6664
  • Use typing_extensions.TypeAlias for PYI026 fixes on pre-3.10 by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6696
  • Ignore multi-comparisons in repeated-equality-comparison-target by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6705
  • Accept empty inner calls in C414 by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6725
  • Allow next in FBT exclusions by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6729
  • Allow ctypes.WinError() in flake8-raise by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6731
  • Ignore star imports when importing symbols in fixes by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6743
  • Support C419 autofixes for set comprehensions by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6744
  • Avoid attempting to fix unconventional submodule imports by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6745
  • Don't trigger eq-without-hash when __hash__ is explicitly set to None by @​LaBatata101 in astral-sh/ruff#6739
  • Avoid E231 if comma is at end-of-line by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6747
  • Truncate some messages in diagnostics by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6748
  • Fix isolation groups for unused imports by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6774
  • Avoid fixing D200 for docstrings that end in escapes by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6779
  • Parenthesize expressions prior to LibCST parsing by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6742
  • Fallback to end-of-file if ends in trailing continuation by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6789
  • Confine repeated-equality-comparison-target to names and attributes by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6802
  • Fix native-literals handling of int literal with attribute access by @​zanieb in astral-sh/ruff#6792
  • Fix uncessary-coding-comment fix when there's leading content by @​zanieb in astral-sh/ruff#6775
  • Avoid attempting to fix PT018 in multi-statement lines by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6829
  • Update ERA100 to apply to commented dictionary items with trailing comments by @​zanieb in astral-sh/ruff#6822
  • Avoid parsing other parts of a format specification if replacements are present by @​zanieb in astral-sh/ruff#6858
  • Avoid panic in unused arguments rule for parameter-free lambda by @​charliermarsh in astral-sh/ruff#6679
  • Avoid C417 for lambda with default and variadic parameters by @​dhruvmanila in astral-sh/ruff#6752
  • Add networkx to conventional aliases by @​zanieb in astral-sh/ruff#6778
  • Skip serializing cell ID if it's None by @​harupy in astral-sh/ruff#6851
  • fix is_raw_string for multiple prefixes by @​davidszotten in astral-sh/ruff#6865
  • Add jupyter notebook cell ids in 4.5+ if missing by @​konstin in astral-sh/ruff#6853

Clean up setup.py in favor of pyproject.toml (#4879)

### Description
<!-- - Describe your changes. -->

- Move much of the metadata from setup.py to pyproject.toml. Setuptools
commands are left unchanged.
- Replace `--weekly_build` with the env var `ONNX_PREVIEW_BUILD`.
Version number verified locally and in CI.
	> **Note**
> Due to `pyproject.toml` limitation, we need to use a script to rename
the package for the weekly build.
> On Windows, it is `(Get-Content -Path 'pyproject.toml') |
ForEach-Object { $_ -replace 'name = "onnx"', 'name = "onnx-weekly"' } |
Set-Content -Path 'pyproject.toml'`
> On linux, it is `sed -i 's/name = "onnx"/name = "onnx-weekly"/'
'pyproject.toml'`
	> Tested locally.
- Replace all `setup.py xxx` usage with `pip install` or `python -m
build` according to setuptools' suggestions.
- The MacOS wheel's platform name needs to be tweaked. Previously it was
modified by supplying the `-p` or `--plat-name` option to `setup.py`.
Now that we use `python -m build`, I created an env var
`ONNX_WHEEL_PLATFORM_NAME` and supply it via the `setup` call:
    ```
	setuptools.setup(
	    ...
	    options={"bdist_wheel": {"plat_name": ONNX_WHEEL_PLATFORM_NAME}}
	    if ONNX_WHEEL_PLATFORM_NAME is not None
	    else {},
	)
	```

### Motivation and Context
<!-- - Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!-- - If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->

https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/latest/userguide/pyproject_config.html

> Starting with [PEP 621](https://peps.python.org/pep-0621/), the Python
community selected pyproject.toml as a standard way of specifying
project metadata. Setuptools has adopted this standard and will use the
information contained in this file as an input in the build process.

https://pypi.org/project/pytest-runner/

> It is recommended that you:
> Remove 'pytest-runner' from your setup_requires, preferably removing
the setup_requires option.
> Remove 'pytest' and any other testing requirements from tests_require,
preferably removing the tests_requires option.
> Select a tool to bootstrap and then run tests such as tox.

fix #4878 and https://github.com/onnx/onnx/issues/4539

---------

Signed-off-by: Justin Chu <justinchu@microsoft.com>
Signed-off-by: Justin Chu <justinchuby@users.noreply.github.com>

issue.title: Create in-memory large models without serializing large initializers through protobuf
issue.body:
### Description

This PR proposes a way to build a large model (> 2Gb) in memory.

### Motivation and Context

The API for external data requires to create the whole model and then to call a function to move big initializer to external files. It creates class `LargeModelContainer`. It holds a ModelProto with no big initializers. The big initiliazers are in an additional dictionary with no protobuf structure (so it can be higher than 2Gb). 

As an example, the creation of a large model:

```python
X = make_tensor_value_info("X", TensorProto.FLOAT, [None, None])
Y = make_tensor_value_info("Y", TensorProto.FLOAT, [None])
graph = make_graph(
    [
        make_node("MatMul", ["X", "A"], ["XA"]),
        make_node("MatMul", ["XA", "B"], ["XB"]),
        make_node("MatMul", ["XB", "C"], ["Y"]),
    ],
    "mm",
    [X],
    [Y],
    [
        # first large tensor, only the type and shape are used,
        # the location must start with '#' and be unique.
        make_large_tensor_proto("#loc0", "A", TensorProto.FLOAT, (3, 3)),
        from_array(np.arange(9).astype(np.float32).reshape((-1, 3)), name="B"),
        # second large tensor, only the type and shape are used
        make_large_tensor_proto("#loc1", "C", TensorProto.FLOAT, (3, 3)),
    ],
)
onnx_model = make_model(graph)

# The second parameter is a dictionary mapping the locations (or unique names) to the numpy arrays,
# it could be easily extended to support torch tensor.
large_model = make_large_model(
    onnx_model.graph,
    {
        "#loc1": (np.arange(9) * 100).astype(np.float32).reshape((-1, 3)),
        "#loc2": (np.arange(9) + 10).astype(np.float32).reshape((-1, 3)),
    },
)
large_model.check_model()

```

comment.body: onnx supports external tensors -> the protobuf structure only contains a filename (any string) and the tensors is stored outside as a binary file. So ONNX spec does allow a ModelProto/GraphProto referencing a non-proto file as weight external data.

issue.title: Create in-memory large models without serializing large initializers through protobuf
issue.body:
### Description

This PR proposes a way to build a large model (> 2Gb) in memory.

### Motivation and Context

The API for external data requires to create the whole model and then to call a function to move big initializer to external files. It creates class `LargeModelContainer`. It holds a ModelProto with no big initializers. The big initiliazers are in an additional dictionary with no protobuf structure (so it can be higher than 2Gb). 

As an example, the creation of a large model:

```python
X = make_tensor_value_info("X", TensorProto.FLOAT, [None, None])
Y = make_tensor_value_info("Y", TensorProto.FLOAT, [None])
graph = make_graph(
    [
        make_node("MatMul", ["X", "A"], ["XA"]),
        make_node("MatMul", ["XA", "B"], ["XB"]),
        make_node("MatMul", ["XB", "C"], ["Y"]),
    ],
    "mm",
    [X],
    [Y],
    [
        # first large tensor, only the type and shape are used,
        # the location must start with '#' and be unique.
        make_large_tensor_proto("#loc0", "A", TensorProto.FLOAT, (3, 3)),
        from_array(np.arange(9).astype(np.float32).reshape((-1, 3)), name="B"),
        # second large tensor, only the type and shape are used
        make_large_tensor_proto("#loc1", "C", TensorProto.FLOAT, (3, 3)),
    ],
)
onnx_model = make_model(graph)

# The second parameter is a dictionary mapping the locations (or unique names) to the numpy arrays,
# it could be easily extended to support torch tensor.
large_model = make_large_model(
    onnx_model.graph,
    {
        "#loc1": (np.arange(9) * 100).astype(np.float32).reshape((-1, 3)),
        "#loc2": (np.arange(9) + 10).astype(np.float32).reshape((-1, 3)),
    },
)
large_model.check_model()

```

comment.body: FYI the converted flatbuffers schema from onnx.proto: https://github.com/justinchuby/onnx-flatbuffers/blob/main/onnx-flatbuffers/onnx.fbs

issue.title: Create in-memory large models without serializing large initializers through protobuf
issue.body:
### Description

This PR proposes a way to build a large model (> 2Gb) in memory.

### Motivation and Context

The API for external data requires to create the whole model and then to call a function to move big initializer to external files. It creates class `LargeModelContainer`. It holds a ModelProto with no big initializers. The big initiliazers are in an additional dictionary with no protobuf structure (so it can be higher than 2Gb). 

As an example, the creation of a large model:

```python
X = make_tensor_value_info("X", TensorProto.FLOAT, [None, None])
Y = make_tensor_value_info("Y", TensorProto.FLOAT, [None])
graph = make_graph(
    [
        make_node("MatMul", ["X", "A"], ["XA"]),
        make_node("MatMul", ["XA", "B"], ["XB"]),
        make_node("MatMul", ["XB", "C"], ["Y"]),
    ],
    "mm",
    [X],
    [Y],
    [
        # first large tensor, only the type and shape are used,
        # the location must start with '#' and be unique.
        make_large_tensor_proto("#loc0", "A", TensorProto.FLOAT, (3, 3)),
        from_array(np.arange(9).astype(np.float32).reshape((-1, 3)), name="B"),
        # second large tensor, only the type and shape are used
        make_large_tensor_proto("#loc1", "C", TensorProto.FLOAT, (3, 3)),
    ],
)
onnx_model = make_model(graph)

# The second parameter is a dictionary mapping the locations (or unique names) to the numpy arrays,
# it could be easily extended to support torch tensor.
large_model = make_large_model(
    onnx_model.graph,
    {
        "#loc1": (np.arange(9) * 100).astype(np.float32).reshape((-1, 3)),
        "#loc2": (np.arange(9) + 10).astype(np.float32).reshape((-1, 3)),
    },
)
large_model.check_model()

```

comment.body:
> The initial PR was creating a single file for large models. In that sense, it was implementing a new serialization format. But I reduced the scope of this PR. Now it is just about having a more intuitive and more efficient way to build large models. The large initializers don't go through protobuf. 
Out of curiosity, does ONNX spec allow a ModelProto/GraphProto referencing a non-proto file as weight? Would endianess of the target platform bring any compatibility issue if the model is, say, serialized in a big-endian system and loaded into a little-endian platform?

> That said, how would you access the nodes, the graph structure after a model is loaded with flatbuffer? Would you convert the graph into protobuf to use the existing code or would you write a new API based on flatbuffer?
We would write a new API that access nodes, etc in an agnostic way. The idea was to standardize ONNX IR using an agnostic serialization format as opposed to use proto files to describe graph, model, nodes, values, etc. 

Protobuf would still be the default serialization format and we could try to make this redesign as BC compatible as possible
